This is a common surgical procedure for weight loss in patients who are severely obese and have failed to achieve significant weight loss through diet and exercise.

The procedure involves making several small incisions in the abdomen, through which a laparoscope (a thin tube with a camera and light on the end) and other instruments are inserted. The surgeon then dissects the omentum and identifies the transverse colon, dividing it from the small bowel. A white load gia stapler is used to divide the small bowel, and a ligasure device is used to divide the mesentery.

Next, the distal bowel is divided, and a hole is made at the antimesenteric portion of the roux limb and the antimesenteric portion of the duodenogastric limb. The edges of the defect are reapproximated with another white load stapler, and the mesenteric defect is closed with interrupted surgidac sutures.

The omentum is then divided all the way down to the colon to create a passageway for the small bowel to go antecolic. The surgeon then places a liver retractor, dissects the angle of his, and dissects on the lesser curve approximately 2.5 cm below the gastroesophageal junction. A 45 blue load stapler is then fired transversely across the stomach to create a gastric pouch.

An EEA stapler is then passed through the end of the roux limb and an anvil, and the spike is joined with the anvil. A stapler is fired to create an end-to-side anastomosis, and the redundant portion of the roux limb is divided with a white load gi stapler. The anastomosis is then secured with additional 2-0 vicryl sutures.

Finally, a bowel clamp is placed across the bowel, and an EGD scope is passed into the mouth down to the esophagus and into the gastric pouch. The pouch is distended with air, and there is no air leak or bleeding seen through the scope. The incisions are then closed with running monocryl suture, and sponge, instrument, and needle counts are performed to ensure everything is accounted for.
